channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: N.S.A. Leaker Denies Giving Classified Data to China
item.description: In an online question-and-answer session, Edward J. Snowden said that he had not given any classified materials to the government of China, calling such speculation “a predictable smear.”
item.dc:creator: By CHARLIE SAVAGE and SCOTT SHANE

item.title: Czech Governing Party Moves to Form New Government
item.description: The jockeying began after Prime Minister Petr Necas resigned over a scandal involving a close aide.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Room for Debate: Hopes for Change in Iran
item.description: Will the election of a moderate cleric lead to real reform, or will powerful forces protect the status quo?

item.title: President-Elect of Iran Talks of Easing Tensions With U.S.
item.description: Speaking for the first time since his election victory, Hassan Rowhani called Iran’s nonexistent ties with the United States a “wound” that must be healed.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: France Télécom Board Backs Chief Executive
item.description: The company’s board stood behind Stéphane Richard after he was placed under formal investigation last week in connection with suspected fraud in a 2008 case.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID JOLLY

item.title: Syria and Russia Warn West Against Aiding Rebels
item.description: Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain said Monday that he found some elements of the Syrian opposition worrying, as Russia warned against arming the rebels.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: 8 Arrested in Tokyo Fights Involving Anti-Korean Group
item.description: Fistfights broke out between ultranationalist Japanese shouting anti-Korean slogans and counterprotesters on the streets of Tokyo, where public violence is rare.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: June 17
item.description: Heavy rains cause road damage in a town in the northern state of Uttarakhand.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: A road damaged after heavy rains near the town of Govindghat in Uttarakhand.

item.title: Montreal Mayor Faces Bribery Charges
item.description: Michael Applebaum, the first English speaker to hold the post in 100 years, was arrested at his home by an anticorruption police squad.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN

item.title: North Korea to Send Senior Envoy to China
item.description: The strategic talks will focus on bilateral relations and the situation on the Korean Peninsula.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: China Court Ruling Could Threaten Foreign Investments in Country
item.description: A recent Supreme People’s Court ruling has highlighted the precariousness of contracts behind major foreign investments in some big Chinese companies.
item.dc:creator: By SUE-LIN WONG
item.media:description: A Baidu conference in Beijing. Baidu is one of the companies that has created a variable interest entity.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Defenders of Public Spaces Take Inspiration From Turkish Protests
item.description: The Turkish protest movement began as a reaction to the impending loss of Istanbul’s Gezi Park to make way for a shopping mall. Campaigns elsewhere indicate that fears about the privatization of public space are not confined to Turkey.
item.dc:creator: By HARVEY MORRIS
item.media:description: Anti-G8 protesters at London's Canary Wharf financial district on Friday.

item.title: India Ink: A Conversation With: Journalist Naveen Soorinje
item.description: A reporter speaks about his time in an Indian prison.
item.dc:creator: By ROHINI MOHAN

item.title: Crowds Protest as Indonesian Lawmakers Consider Raising Fuel Prices
item.description: The government has said reducing spending on gasoline subsidies could help close a budget gap, but opponents say it will cause painful inflation.
item.dc:creator: By JOE COCHRANE

item.title: Letter From Europe: The Pope and the Archbishop
item.description: About the only thing that Pope Francis and the Most Rev. Justin Welby share is the fact that they are outsiders in their respective churches. Beyond that, institutional and doctrinal differences remain deep.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: India Ink: As Rape Reports Increase in Delhi, a Call for Uncommon Men and Women
item.description: The tide of rising crimes against women in India can eventually be stemmed by uncommon women and men.
item.dc:creator: By KAVITA NANDINI RAMDAS
item.media:description: Men lying down on the ground mimicking dead bodies at a protest on Dec. 29, 2012, as they mourned the death of a 23-year-old woman who was gang raped in Delhi on Dec. 16.

item.title: Obama Addresses Youth in Belfast
item.description: Before joining Group of 8 leaders, President Obama hailed the normalcy in Belfast and the economic growth, despite Europe’s recent hard times.
item.dc:creator: By JACKIE CALMES
item.media:description: President Obama acknowledged “wounds that haven’t healed" but mostly praised Northern Ireland on Monday in Belfast.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: IHT Quick Read: June 17
item.description: New leaks indicate U.S. and British eavesdropping; Turkey cracks down on protests; debating the right to be forgotten; Japanese women in science; and high expectations for a young Brazilian soccer player.
item.dc:creator: By THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE
item.media:description: Turkish police officers are seen taking medical personnel into custody near Taksim Square on Sunday.

item.title: From Inner Circle of Iran, a Pragmatic Victor
item.description: Analysts say a priority of Iran’s president-elect, Hassan Rowhani, will be mediating the strained relationship between the citizens and the conservative leadership.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:description: Iran's president-elect, Hassan Rowhani, is seen as a cautious realist, but no ideologue.

item.title: New Leak Indicates Britain and U.S. Tracked Diplomats
item.description: A disclosure of documents obtained by Edward J. Snowden suggests the countries eavesdropped at 2009 conferences.
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SHANE and RAVI SOMAIYA

item.title: New Governor Shock to Some Inside Egypt
item.description: The new governor of Luxor, Adel Asaad Khayyat, comes from the political arm of an Islamist group that once carried out terrorist attacks.
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD and MAYY EL SHEIKH

item.title: Kuwait Court Dissolves Parliament and Calls Vote That Opposition May Boycott
item.description: The opposition had asked the court to reject changes to the way votes are cast, saying that the new system will make it more difficult to form alliances.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: U.S. Seems Eager for Nuclear Talks With Iran’s New Leader
item.description: President Obama’s top foreign policy aides said they planned to press Hassan Rowhani, Iran’s president-elect, to resume negotiations over his country’s nuclear program.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Joyce’s ‘Finnegans Wake’ Takes Off in China
item.description: As Bloomsday nears this Sunday, the Chinese translator of James Joyce’s “Finnegans Wake” explains while the book is very difficult to understand even for English-speaking readers, somehow it has struck a nerve in China.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: A large billboard in Beijing advertising the translated work of James Joyce's "Finnegans Wake."

item.title: Turkey Expands Violent Reaction to Street Unrest
item.description: Turkish authorities took aim not just at the demonstrators in Taksim Square, but also at the medics who treated their injuries and the business owners who sheltered them.
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO, SEBNEM ARSU and CEYLAN YEGINSU
item.media:description: Turkish police officers are seen taking medical personnel into custody near Taksim Square on Sunday.
